description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9biAMvQcPLe

This is for a Hypercube Evolution with 3030 extrusion. There are multiple options for holding the filament. You can use the regular arm or longer arm and closed nut cap. Or you can print the 8mm rod plug and use a 8mm threaded rod and nuts with your choice of bearing spools. I have found the plug option to have a little sag with a full roll. Nothing that I fear will break but you may want to up infil for that option on the base. This holder sits inside by 40mm. That is 40mm from the inside edge of the extrusion to the back edge of the holder. My printer has aprox 50mm of room so no danger of it clearing.

on the rod version I used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:969358 for the quick release lock
and I used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480167 for the bearing spool holders.

When I ordered cappuccino in Costa at Gatwick airport the lady asked me if I want frog on it. I said yes, not being sure if this is some new british euphemism that she may take personally if I decline. But my worries were eased when I just got a lovely cocoa powder frog stenciled on top of my (very) large cappuccino.
Since then I always wanted Gatwick Frog of my own. And here we are, years later I am sharing this with all of you so you can drink cappuccino the only correct way. This is my very own artistic recreation of the frog stencil from Gatwick, from a picture I took of my coffee that day.

Print in PLA.
This will be just 6 layers (total of 1.2mm thickness at 0.2mm per layer)
use 2 solid layers on top and bottom and then infill 10% fast honeycomb, and it just looks and works absolutely perfect.
This is a 13 cm diameter stencil so it works on wide cappuccino mugs.

How to Gatwick Frog stencil cappuccino.
Place the stencil just ABOVE the foam, and sift cocoa powder through it. Don't rest the stencil on the foam directly because the foam will stick and when you remove it, it will mess the image. I actually put foam just below the rim of my cup and then rest my stencil on top of my cup.
I call my days good or bad frog day depending how the stencil turns out to be. I am almost pretty sure it actually rains when the frog doesn't turn out nicely. Or the other way.

You are welcome to post pics of your stenciled Gatwick frog cappuccino.

remixed_from.title: Bowden setup for E3D Hotend on Prusa I2

title: E3D Low Profile mount with 40mm fan

description.text: This is a combination of ideas - the low profile design of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:154938 and the 40mm fan mount of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:94086. I bought an E3D Bowden hot end for my Prusa Mendel & loved it, but it cut my usable height to ~70mm. Also, I didn't have 24v available for the 30mm fan, so I wanted to use a standard, quiet 40mm with decent airflow. Now my girlfriend can sleep & I can print up to ~145mm I purposefully left the mounting holes off the model because things didn't fit so well on my printer & I had to re-drill & adjust.

I printed at 40% fill & lined it up with a previous mount to drill the holes. Once drilled, I fed the hot end up from below the X carriage, loosely attached the clamp piece, then bolted the assembly to the X carriage. Mine was a little high, so I pushed the hot end down slightly to give it a little clearance (only about 1-2mm between the print bed & the zip ties holding the bearings). Then I tightened everything in place, attached the fan, adjusted the end stop, & printed!.

author: Broadsword85

title: Non Circular Gears
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Non circular gears - (superellipse, ellipse, circular)

First attempt on some heavy functional programming in openSCAD
It's not quick but it gets the job done.
A C# program will calculate in 10 - 100ms with 16000 iterations
Here iterations are limited by recursion max, and at best it takes 40 sec to calculate, more often longer up to 8 min seen.
The number of iterations could be lowered, but the best results
come with high numbers, so I left it high at 5000
With numbers higher than 5000 I begin to get recurse error
###################################################################
Only enable one drawPolarGearSet as each can take more minuts to calculate, and lock openScad until done.
If you get recurse errors - try
Edit->Prefrerences
Advanced tap
set "Turn off rendering" to 4000000 it works on my setup
###################################################################

More info about Non circular gears can be found in my article at
codeproject - search for "Drawing Gears - Circular and Non Circular"
As the C# version requires more support programs, like Sketchup with STL export addon to generate the STL files and some knowledge of Ruby.

This all inclusive openSCAD version is more easy to use.

If you don't wan't to play around with parameters in openSCAD the stl files are ready to be printed

Naming of STL files:

major axis, minor axis, power, revolutions, centerInFocalPoint, maximumLengthBetweenPoints, numberOfTeeth

Scale 0.85 has been applied to:

  • 25_15_4_1_true.stl
  • 25_15_4_2_true.stl
  • 25_15_4_3_true.stl
  • 25_15_4_4_true.stl
    this ensure the largest 25_15_4_4_true.stl fit my printbed

Scale 2 has been applied to:

  • 15_15_4_1_false_dot125.stl
  • 15_15_5_1_false_dot125.stl
  • 15_15_6_1_false_dot25.stl
  • 15_15_7_1_false_dot35_48.stl
  • 15_15_8_1_false_dot35_64.stl
  • 15_15_9_1_false_dot40_72.stl
    this ensure the fine teeth on the last gear can be printed

All other stl files (I haven't printed yet) are unscaled

ToDo:
Other parametric gear designers have added helix, herringbone to normal gears
Planetary gear sets.

Have printed many gear sets and they all mesh and run, some of the of the gears with offset to the centers have to be helped to turn as teeth can pop out of mesh due to gravity and/or load forces.
Have used scale to adjust the size of gears to fit my printer, the largest gear set in a serie determin the the scale to be used for all sets in the serie.
This scaling was done in ReplicatorG as I prepare the STL to be printed, you could do it in the openSCAD before saving the STL with a small change to the code.

For the more math/programming interested this could be used for study:

Some good learning can be made and some things I haven't figured out yet.

  • Best search algorithm, to find optimal center distance.
    -- Why does the methode used work better than a standard binary search?
  • How to speed things up in a program language with alot of limits.
    -- Skipping calculations
    -- Tweeking tolerances
    -- Limit iterations
  • How to overcome the jump in values the power functions used to generate the superellipse data has.
    -- Line function
  • How to get enough data points to get a good aproximation of perimeter length/tooth placement.
    -- Tweeking tolerances
    -- Line function
  • How to use functional programming, to solve a complex problem.

Have fun..

description.text:
This is intended to be a fun notice-board or fridge magnet design, based on our dog, a black poodle named Shadow.

It was also a first experiment with 3D design and printing for me and my daughter.

We started from a photo of Shadow curled-up on a sofa, loaded that into Sketchup, and manually traced the outline. Then we closed the shapes, pulled it into 3 dimensions, and added a hole in the back for the magnet to go.

I'm sure there are smaller quantities of magnets available, but we went for value for money with a batch of 50 as follows:
http://www.banggood.com/50pcs-N52-Super-Strong-Disc-Magnets-20mm-x-3mm-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Magnets-p-997169.html

Originally we did a 20mm diameter hole for the magnet, but that needed widening to fit the magnets in, so the uploaded file has the hole enlarged to 21mm diameter. We glued the magnets in place with a small blob of Araldite.

After a little bit of searching around, I chose to print this with 3dprint-uk.co.uk, using their (only) material 'PA2200 Nylon', and carbon-black and polish processing options. This did end up with a larger order quantity than I had originally envisaged, so I wonder if we might go through something like 3dhubs.com if doing it again, but we were certainly very pleased with the product look, feel, and overall quality from 3dprint-uk.

This came out very well to represent our black poodle. See some photos attached.

It was a fun project, and has given us some lovely friendly magnets to use and share with family and friends.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bRBnX3T7UGz

title: Slotted open bar clamp for Prusa Mendel iteration 2

description.text:
Open ended bar clamp.

Cracked a bar clamp from over tightening? Cut it off and replace it with this, it has an open ended design so it can be fitted without taking apart the frame. It slips onto the 8mm threaded rod.

Very tight fit, some careful cleanup with a 8mm or 8.5mm drill bit maybe needed.

Not as strong as the original but it does the job. Works best if printed with ABS as ABS is more flexible. If printing with PLA, be careful not to overtighten as it will crack. This is exactly the same as the original bar-clamp for the Prusa Mendel but with a slot cut into it.

OpenSCAD provided is slightly modified from the original. Some dependencies from the original source are needed.

remixed_from.title: 12000 mA/h 18650 Battery Pack and dual USB recharger

description.text:
*updated on 02/11/17 with shorter nipple and new pic

Why do i do this? Because no powerbank in the market is good enough for my needs or at their best performance or quality. When I build my own, I know i put the best in it, benefit as below,

  • true dual 2A output, (it's capable of 3A in actual load test, but phone limits draw at 2A)
  • high quality 18650 cell, the same as in Tesla
  • discharge cut off at 3V, fully utilise capacity of the battery at 80% rule, some in the market cut at high 3.7v, too early
  • able to recharge the powerbank at 2A, vs only 0.5A for those in market

Here's the video reviewing my powerbank
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WTpypuS-RZw

This is remixed due to the original quite narrow width to fit the 18650 batteries. Also the circuit board/module seems a bit different hence require trimming. So I drew one from the ground up based on the dimension from original creator.

It's tested to fit perfectly with the diy powerbank module purchased below.
Single module
https://go.edwardrc.com/2nv0XVU

3x module (more recommended so you have backup module in case...)
https://go.edwardrc.com/2jdBhJ0

Panasonic NCR18650B - Good, Cheap, Quality been tested on this project and my drones.
4 of these are soldered in parallel, not series. So you get 4x3400mah, where in the market usually 4x2500mah only.
http://bit.ly/2ncwWdt

Am very happy with the board above as it's verified to output 2A and input is 2A too! hence it gets "rejuiced" very quickly

For my own version, I just cover it with a 2.75mm thickness clear acrylic board to show off the inner parts. secured with either tiny screw or hotglue.

As for the LED, I de-solder and relocated it to point forward, just drill a 5mm hole, SLOWLY!

Do comment if it works well for you, I'll be happy to hear that

author: jotte

description.text:
I've used dual computer monitors for almost 30 years, and while there are always the bezels between them, there has also always been an annoying gap and usually some degree of misalignment between the two. It didn't matter much because I usually have a different application on each monitor and rarely needed to have an application spread across both. But I finally got tired of the gap and printed these clips that snap over the top and bottom edges of the bezels. They hold the bezels aligned at the correct angle and minimize the gap between the two. The remaining small gap disappeared with the application of a strip of black electrical tape.

These clips certainly aren't going to fit your monitors (unless they happen to be HP LA2405x) so the OpenSCAD file is parametric and the dimensions are clearly identified so you can alter it and size them to your monitor pair*. The top and bottom clips may need to be different sizes. I'm going to reprint the clips shown in a less obtrusive black, and make them a little taller to allow some double-sided tape to be applied underneath, and a bit longer to make it a bit more stable.

I should have done this years ago. After using them this way for only a few hours, I find myself stretching applications across the gap and using them as if on a single monitor. With the perfect alignment and the gap gone, my mind seems better able to 'disappear' the center bezels.

*(Yes, I could make this a customizable Thing, but I refuse to do so. It only encourages idiots who publish their customized things that clutter up Thingiverse. You really should learn the basics of OpenSCAD anyway - openscad.org)
Just a few lines of OpenSCAD.

you want more reality at the Ossum jeep by 3danarchy?
for the instruments (thing: 2511807) I have now created a background lighting. the inside of the housing I have white, so the reflection of the led becomes larger, furthermore I have arranged the LED so that it comes to an indirect illumination, because otherwise only the tacho is illuminated. the LED is a red 3mm LED with a 100 Ohm series resistor. The LED is glued in the housing and then the housing is also glued to the instrument expression behind the cockpit. the result can be seen in the pictures. to simulate the assembly, whether this housing fits also, I have the corresponding STL files combined with Simplify3D. after that there should be no problems in assembly.

The Afinibot A1 delta printer has very slappy linear bearings. I added one extra bearing to each of the three carriers to reduce the play. The difference is day and night.
Three new LMB6UU linear bearings are needed. Saw this but have not tried it https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36330
The added bearing house is a little longer than the bearing in case of differences from different brands.

I printed it with ordinary cheep PLA. A little thicker walls and 18% infill. A slight higher temperature and squeesed together extrusion width together wit a little slower printing speed makes the part not nicer but stronger.

title: Hollow pyramid on a square base

description.text: A customizable (OpenSCAD) hollow pyramid consisting of four equilateral triangles around a square base.  The size of the pyramid and the thickness of its five enclosing walls are parameters that can be specified.

I printed it on borosilicate glass (i.e., pyrex) sprayed with Aqua Net extra super hold hairspray using Printrbot 3mm PLA filament.  I unstuck the print by freezing it for 15 minutes in my refrigerator freezer.  Extruder: 185 degrees C; bed: 70 degrees C; 0.2mm layer thickness; zero density infill.

author: prodrone

title: MassageRoller (cnc)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a quite simple tool to convince someone (e.g. your wife or husband for that matter) why it is absolutely critical to own a cnc-router. So, this really is one more piece of the series: how to make your family love your cnc :)

I used 20 mm plywood which is coated white and cut it with my Stepcraft desktop cnc-machine and a special 3 mm endmill for wood. As the cuts are quite deep it's a good idea to attend the cnc and use the vacuum from time to time to clear out the path.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

The stl is intended for three dimensional viewing only. It will probably not work without further attention.

After cutting I sanded all parts and rounded the edges. Eight 20 mm hex bolts are screwed directly into the handle. Washers and some grease make for smooth and quiet rotation. The wheels actually don't need to spin free. A bit of resistance does not hurt.

The geometry did cost some effort, but after several tries I had a handle that can be used by regular sized male and female hands. Here is one tipp, I'd like to share: in order to save material I printed out several paper templates. It let me determine the workability of a given design without cutting and I had the chance to use up scrap pieces because I could verify the design will fit on a certain part.

This is a Knife Handle and Sheath made for a Damascus Knife. Here is the Knife i bought from Ebay.

http://www.ebay.com/itm/Custom-Fire-Damascus-Steel-Drop-Point-Blank-Blade-J620-For-Hunting-Knife-/253057750135?_trksid=p2047675.l2557&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&nma=true&si=%252FBsP7zF2ryjqsJFfJREY7m8T%252Bb8%253D&orig_cvip=true&rt=nc

I remixed it from the Knife Sheath by gleiberkid and the handle was remixed from Custom Jörg Sprave Rambone by piksteel.

I used Tinkercad and Meshmixer to remix everything. The sheath is strongest if you print it on it's side just like it is with full supports. The handle halves are stongest printed laying flat with supports on the bottom. I used 3mm bolts and lock nuts in the handle and in the clip. I used PETG filament to print this.

title: ABS print with Verdigris Copper finish

description.text:
This is the face of a beautiful young woman that was printed in ABS. It was painted with metal effects reactive copper paint.  The patina is SculptNouveau Tiffany Green.  
What you see is a layer of actual copper particles reacting to the acid patina.

comments.text: How did you get a later of copper particles on your print to use the patina?
comments.author: nickg102

comments.text: There is a product called "Metal Effects Oxidizing Copper Paint".  It is a paint base mixed with fine copper particles.
comments.author: nickg102

comments.text: Thanks.  It probably helps that I have done a lot of patina on solid copper.  I actually find the reactive paint easier because it is a lot more uniform than real copper.  Real copper always has an oxide layer on it which affects how the patina reacts in different places.  SculptNouveau is a great resource for patina.  Ron Young, the owner, is one of the masters of the art.  He makes a 2 part reactive metal coating which cures hard enough that it can be polished.  I've never used it, but it sounds cool.
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text: Mate, you did a pretty good job. I have done lots of this before, so i know how hard it can be sometimes to get the right amount of patina.
comments.author: se7en

comments.text: I hadn't herd of that brand before. Thx for the info. Artists in the 3d printing world need this!
comments.author: se7en

author: Shapespeare

title: E3D Chimera on Velleman Vertex K8400
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an Is my project to build a Vertex which can also print ABS, PC...
My Problem was that the Vertex can't reach enough high temps for printing interessting Materials, so I built my own. I read a lot about de E3D heads but it's to expensive and to big for me, so I bought the Chimera (also E3D) and planned to put it on the Vertex with Succsess. Unlike the E3D V6 you don't loose printing volume, if you do it like here.

At the moment I just uploaded the two 3D models, If there's much interest and some donates for the time, I'll make an excact Instruction for what you need, what's to do in de Programm code, how you can get above 270 degrees and how you have to edit the E3D Chimera...

(Sorry for my bad English)

Vertex K8400

comments.text:
Thanks for your reply! A picture where I can see how you fix the heatsink to the printed part (I think from above).
At what temeratures are you printing?
Where did you find the cad models ? (which I can see in the firts picture) Your design is perfect but I want to change it a bit and therefore it will be nice to have the CAD-files from the printhead etc...
comments.author: FilipPeeters

comments.text:
I found a picture from above and posted it. I use the normal 3 holes and screws to mount it.
The temperatures at PC are very different. for example the PC from www.3dware.ch is recommended at 280°Celsius on the other hand, the PC from Renkforce is recommended at 240°Celsius. and there are some other special plastics like PEEK, but i didn't tested it yet.
I found the CAD models at this link:
https://forum.vellemanprojects.eu/t/chimera-mount-first-design-attempt/12736
This is the only project I found for the Chimera, but I wasn't satisfied with it, thats why I did my project.
And an important Info for you, I had to realize that these CAD models are wrong.
If you want to make a 3D model, you can check out the E3D, because they have technical drawings of the parts.
And If you just need to know where to drill the hole. I designed it to work if you drill the hole through the existing lower of the 3 threaded holes, which are at the back of the chimera.
comments.author: FilipPeeters

comments.text: Thank you for the info!

During the time, I even built in the PT100 temperature sensor to be able printing at higher temp.

comments.text: If you want an opinion of a mechanical engineering student, tinkerer and hobbiest, all of these should work fine, although the 4th one (bottom right) isn't the most efficiently designed, as recesses in bushings like this are normally used for packing in things like lithium grease, and the cutouts on it aren't connected to the main shaft channel, so it wouldn't lubricate. The second one (top right) is the most likely to break if you over-tightened them, but aside from that, if these are used in the way they are meant to be used, they should work fine.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4G0osi28SNP

someone wanted an islamic door so i had a fast go using HGT2STL included here, instructions:

get an image, in gimp adjust levels/curves, change to mode/index to reduce colors, convert back to RGB, splash fill zones of it, do filters/gaussian blur 2pxl and perhaps again at 4pxl if you prefer.

save to PNG

open in HGT2STL
invert BW if you want
save to STL

open in meshlab 2017 (stabler awesome version)
use filters/remesh/quadratic edge, check options 1-5 and 7 and set to .5 simplification or higher
save your mesh

you can select connected parts in meshlab or explode into different components connected also in the options of select and mesh entity at the right.

vector mandalas are fun for hgt conversion.

have fun!

remixed_from.title: Fan mount for Buda hot end

title: Fan mount for Buda's hot end adapted to Greg's extruder

description.text: The original fan mount from JesusGomez (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:186143) cannot be used with a Buda adapter (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:57668). This modified version should solve the problem (to be tested with real pieces).

Buda's hot end is secured to extruder using a special adapter.
M4 bolts enters from bottom and nuts have their holes on top of extruder's base.
Holes on "wings" should be used to insert bolts and screwdriver. Standard M4 bolts have a head of about 8mm, but it's not possible to make a hole of such diameter, so a smaller head bolt is required, because I'm not sure it will be possible to insert the bolt from the side.
I didn't print this thing, but I largely tested it on sketchup. If someone could print it, please let me know the results.

3DPlastX filaments rock. Period.
3DPlastx spools suck. Period.

In order to use this very affordable filament to its full potential, a proper spool holder must be utillised. If you use an enclosure, this spool holder is the top of the line for your application.

This design uses two legendary emmett gear bearings modified to perfectly fit to the ever so problematic cardboard - tin spools and makes them super easy to rotate.

If you like this design and find it useful, feel free to send something with a few zeros behind the dot, something like this: 0.00001 BTC
My Bitcoin address is: 1FdDcAuVjmLq5iVdjcktrnUsPqi8CuPdRz
Thank you very much.

If it won't rotate, push it hard in the center until you hear cracking, then do the same on the other side. Use a drill to work the bearing for easier rotation.

Threading it onto the rod can be quite a challenge. Hold two of the planetary gears tightly to prevent the sun gear from rotating. When the thread is complete, you can use the printable tool to rotate the emmett bearing into position. Afterwards, use a single M10 nut to secure the bearing in place.

The solar panel attachment can be slid onto the back, and the solar panels glued to it. This approach was chosen so you can print the panels and attachment in different colors than the spaceship for enhanced contrast.

Enjoy the space exploration ;)

title: Filament Guide, Sensor, Cleaner & Cable management for the CR-10 with MK8 Aluminium Extruder

description.text:
Filament Guide, Sensor, Cleaner & Cable management for the CR-10 with MK8 Aluminium Extruder

Note: these parts are very much still prototypes and need testing and feedback

With the Aluminium upgrade, you can't really put something over the top like on the stock MK8 extruder so this bracket is designed to sit under the MK8 and brings together many things into an all in one bracket.

  1. filament out sensor, which is designed to take a small piece of Bowden PTFE tube as an inlet
  2. filament cleaner, which can take any material works for you, I recommend a strip of sponge folded in half.
  3. filament guide, which is designed to use a piece of Bowden PTFE from the cleaner to the Aluminium extruder all the way to the feeder gear
  4. cable management

The sensor is meant to be a common end stop switch. Make sure you get the one where the switch is 90 degrees to the PCB like in the picture.
To buy the sensor simply do a search for "Mechanical Endstop NO Limit Switch" in ebay, amazon etc

To set this up on your Octopi follow the instructions in this youtube vid

and for more details follow the instruction on the Thingiverse this is remixed from
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2480901

Update 1

  • Printed prototype and made many changes
  • No longer rests under MK8
  • Reduced no of parts by 1
  • Reduced the need for supports
  • Sensor section now slides into place and clips in place

Update 2

  • Printed many prototypes and made many tweaks and fixes
  • Improved mounting with screws and attachment to frame
  • Sensor module is now more streamlined

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

As far as I can tell only 1 part needs supports. Refer to the gallery image

Note that these parts have thin walls. Make sure you cater for this in your slicer. It may eventuate that the walls need to be made thicker, and if so ill update the models.

Assembly

Assembly is easier when the filament is already threaded through the sensor module and the cleaner module. Don't assemble everything and then try to thread the filament it really hard to get into the Bowden tube that leads to the MK8

Add the Bowden tube and insert the sensor facedown. the limit switch arm should angle up towards the sensor module output feed the filament through the sensor module feed the filament through the cleaning module Add cleaning material to the cleaning chamber The above example a uses a strip of sponge about 45-50mm Attach sensor module to cleaning module Attach mount to the CR-10. Unscrew the nut on the lead screw. Make sure the screws are undone high, try not to unscrew them all the way out (easier). Slide the assembly into place and feed the Bowden tube in to the hole on the cleaning module As you slide it into place make sure it goes under and scoops the washers and screws. Once in place re-screw but not tightly. Be aware that these screws are the only screws on the CR-10 that are meant to be loose. Hand tighten and loosen half a rotation, If your z-axis is still not moving smoothly loosen these even more Lastly attach the cable the runs to the hotend

author: man9898

description.text:
The is a case for the Raspberry Pi that is intended to be used as a Bitcoin hardware cold wallet. Note that this will never be as secure as a wallet using a secure element, like a Ledger Nano. The project's namesake, the Trezor, doesn't have a secure element, but is still more secure since its designed by security minded professionals, rather than a DIY project using a Pi Zero. The plus side, is you build it yourself so you know what's in there, and if you take precautions, then you can probably keep this secure.

See my first explorations into this concept here: http://www.allaboutjake.com/pi-offline-crypto-wallet/

I am currently working on software for the Pi to expose an Electrum wallet on the Pi using the a menuing system on the LCD. This will include the signing of transactions using the QR codes and the PiCamera for input and the LCD for output.

If you find this useful, or you'd like to donate to the future development of this system, send some satoshi to the following address: 1PqvzEtDcboQYF2yhMvcdzK3J6uj7SMtQQ

Bill of materials

  • Raspberry Pi Zero (I'm using a W for development, but a non-W is better for a cold wallet)
  • 1.44 ST7735 based LCD: http://r.ebay.com/b7ZpxI
  • 5-Way Tactile Switch: http://r.ebay.com/U5YHC6
  • 5MP Pi Camera: http://r.ebay.com/igagFy
  • 30AWG wire wrap wire (its a tight fit, so I used thin wire)
  • Screws (M2.5x12 for the outside, M2.5x4 for the Pi inside.)

I used OnShape to develop the case. Its kind of a tight fit, but the case does close.

The "middle plate" part is an unintended consequence of not having the right screws. I'm looking to get some M2x2 waver head screws for mounting the parts to the case.

I chose the 128x128 LCD specifically because it was 30mm wide and had more pixels than OLED displays used by other projects. (see http://hackaday.io/project/9564-rpi-zero-wifi-enabled-hardware-password-manager for one such project that uses OLED). More pixels are desirable for QRCode bandwidth.

Some ideas on how this may evolve:

  • A PCB "bonnet" that holds the LCD, and 5-way switch, and maybe some extra hardware
  • A real-time clock module to remember the time
  • A lipo battery? (Its already pretty tight in there, not sure if I can fit it without making the case bigger)
  • Move to buttons (similar to http://hackaday.io/project/9564-rpi-zero-wifi-enabled-hardware-password-manager). The 5-way switch was quick and easy, but I think buttons would be better.

Things that inspired this project, but not specifically a remix

The initial inspiration for this project was the awful "Taken 3" movie where Liam Neeson uses a fictional device to download the GPS history from a car. (I don't recommend this movie). See the frame cap below to see the device.

Other projects to make a Pi Zero-sized user interface to the Pi Zero include:

  • http://hackaday.io/project/9564-rpi-zero-wifi-enabled-hardware-password-manager
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1193350
  • Many GameBoy-like systems like PiGrrl, etc.
I do have a very particular set of skills, skills I have acquired over a very long career.

description.text:
This is my MK3 carriage for a single extruder for the Malayan M180.
I removed the left hand extruder, except for the fan, and thirmister (for some reason it will not work if you remove this) and used the right hand heating block and the filament guide.
You will also need, a 60mm long hot end extruder guide, and a length of aluminum bar 90mm long by 4mm thick. This is the heat sink and mount for the hot end extruder. Drilled and tapped in the centre to M6 with two 6mm mounting holes to attach to the carriage.
I used some M4 brass threaded inserts but you could use nuts and bolts.
I also use M3 inserts to mount the fan.
You will have to adjust the Z axis stop sensor to level the bed, as the heating block protrudes slightly than on the original carriage.
For the filament drive I used a metal Bowden type, which is cheaply available on EBay etc.
and used the left hand fan to cool the stepper motor. This was then fitted to the printer casing above the filament spool, using some scrap aluminum angle.
The whole thing took about 4hrs to complete and set up but the results are worth it.
It is much easier to load filament, the prints are great and I can now reach higher temperatures.

title: East3D Gecko Low-Profile Front Panel Screen Bezel

description.text:
Low-profile Screen Bezel for the Gecko! Designed to cover the exposed guts of the touch screen.

There are 2 designs and a spacer, a more rectangular version and a sharper version with deeper chamfers. The models should have sufficient tolerances (0.6mm for the most parts) to have a good fit on the front panel and screen.

The spacer is designed to reduce the play on the screen, you are supposed to glue the spacer at the right side of the bezel so that it pushes the right side of the screen to reduce/eliminate the play when you are interacting with the touch screen.

No longer will you need to resort to using double faced tape, duct tape, or any odd mounting methods.

title: Real-time Filament Thickness Gage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a way to measure the diameter of the filament that was coming out of OmNom my pellet extruder/recycler so I sat myself down in front of SolidWorks and this is what was squirting out one of my printers a few hours later. Man! I love this technology! To be able to go from a little more than a puff of smoke in the back of my head to in my hand all in a couple of hours!

Apologies in advance to all the metric boys and girls out there but this was designed using imperial fasteners so you will need to source the metric equivalent. Also, being that this tool was intended to be assembled and just get used likely not touching the fasteners again I didn't bother too much with captured nuts.

Here is the list of parts you will need.
PRINTED:
Indicator Holder (either front or side facing) - 1pcs
Indicator Upper Body - 1pcs
Indicator Lower Body - 1pcs
Indicator Riser (pick your preferred height) - 2pcs
Indicator Base - 1pcs

FASTENERS:
4-40 x 1/4" SHCS- 6pcs
4-40 Nuts - 2pcs
6-32 x 3/4" SHCS - 2pcs
6-32 x 1" SHCS- 1pc
8/32 x 1/2" SHCS -2pcs (can substitute allen set screws)
608zz bearings - 2pcs
Bearing axle - 2pcs
(can use printed part, or chunks of 5/16" or 8mm rod no longer than 0.850"

Please Like, share, and post pics if you make one!

title: Bohrschablone für Terassendielen / drilling template for decking boards

description.text:
English below

Eine Bohrschablone für Terassendielen mit 145 mm Breite und 20 bis 25 mm Dicke. Abstand der Bohrungen ist 100 mm. Der Steg sorgt für 3-4 mm Abstand der Dielen und das U greift auf 40mm breite Konstruktionshölzer unter den Dielen. Dadurch sind die Bohrungen immer in einer Linie.
So viele Schablonen wie Reihen Konstruktionshölzer unter der Terasse drucken, Diele auflegen, Schablonen auflegen, an schon vorhandene Diele drücken und mit Edding durch die Bohrungen markieren. Schablone abheben und seitlich versetzt auf der Diele liegen lassen, damit der Abstand weiterhin korrekt ist.
Dann kann man Vorbohren und Festschrauben.
Mit 2 Akkuschraubern zum Bohren und Schrauben geht das Verlegen dann sehr schnell.

A drilling template for decking boards with 145 mm width and 20 to 25 mm thickness. The distance between the holes is 100 mm. The bridge provides for 3-4 mm spacing of the planks and the U is made to center in 40 mm wide construction timbers under the planks. This means that the holes are always in line.
Print as many stencils as rows of construction timbers under the terrace, lay down floorboards, lay drilling templates, press towards existing floorboards and make marks with a pen through the holes. Lift off the template and leave it offset to the side of the board so that the distance remains correct.
Then you can pre-drill and screw tight.
With 2 cordless screwdrivers for drilling and screwing, installation is very fast.

How can the everyday life of wheelchair users be facilitated and enriched? A team of wheelchair users, technicians and designers has worked together on need analysis, idea development, prototyping and testing for solutions for wheelchair add ons. Not only the usability, but also the aesthetic side was taken into account: "We want the wheelchair not to look like old school medical equipment and but to look cool and contemporary" says Raul Krauthausen a project participant. The lighting set open°lights is one of our designs that we developed and improved with several testing rounds. There are two common shapes that we call the I and the O. The I is used for front lights and the floor light. The O is used for a backlighting. The interface of the lights is easy to handle.

With the help of open source instructions and maker technologies in Fab Labs our products can be build and customized by the users.
To get started please download the Thing Files and open the Open Lights DIY Manual.

The "Made for my Wheelchair" project is funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research. Project partners are Makea Industries GmbH, beable e. V. the Otto Bock Mobility Solutions GmbH and the Sozialhelden e.V.

Visit http://www.madeformywheelchair.de/ and learn more about the project.

16 jan 2018:
Updated the clip to have no sharp edges.
Updated the stepper connection part to better fit with the MKS base box.

Original post:
I designed another openable chain as the ones I've tried didn't work, they needed to small parts or simply didn't work as I expected.
The clip on the chain is slightly bendable & stretchable. This makes it very easy to put them on the chain, yet they don't fall off.
Print in PLA but PETG & ABS make the clips more resistant to enthousiastic bending :-).

Scale the clip down or up with 0.3-0.5mm if your printer accuracy is not the same as mine :-)

description.text:
Here's a 1 minute Intro Features Video

I made this all open source and respectfully ask you to consider supporting the project. We successfully funded on Kickstarter with hundreds of kits sold, and now we have our own store. We have more than just the Hexapod electronics, we have all kinds of things useful for small robotics and other projects:
Vorpal Robotics Store with Hexapod Kits and Parts

  • IMPORTANT: If you opt-in to receive our store monthly newsletters you'll automatically be enrolled in a monthly prize drawing, first prize is a $100 store credit and there are lots of other smaller prizes too! Sign up for newsletters here:
  • Vorpal Store Opt-in for Prize Drawing
  • Every store purchase also earns 20% is Store Credit Rewards. Help us grow so we can continue creating cool projects!

What in the World Is It?

This is an awesome 3d printed, open source, Bluetooth controlled, Scratch programmable combat hexapod with a 3d printed gamepad and a bunch of accessories to play different games. I mean, seriously, let that concept wash over you for a moment. You absolutely need this little guy running around your house!

Related Things

The Vorpal Combat Hexapod was built to be extensible. We've already published a bunch of items that are compatible and hope the community will contribute even more.

Related Things by Vorpal Robotics, LLC:
Thing 2539659: Vorpal Joust Game
Thing 2546533: Vorpal Capture the Flag Game
Thing 2555606: Vorpal Fidget Spinner Challenge Game
Thing 2538181: Vorpal Eye Decorations
Thing 2538179: Vorpal Name Plate Decoration
Thing 2548308: Vorpal HC-SR04 Rangefinder Sensor Bracket
Thing 2615267: Vorpal Hexapod Stand

Join our community! Here are some related Things by Vorpal Enthusiasts:
Thing 2797112: Lego Compatible Hexapod Cap
Thing 2730373: Mohawk Hair Decoration
Thing 2743717: Aggressive Eyes
Thing 2723225: Fancy Weaved Top and other mods
Thing 2667661: Nameplate Generator Customizer
Thing 2597686: Blank Nameplate
Thing 2603057: Midieval Hexapod Design based on Vorpal
Thing :2640065: Boots for feet
Thing 2664081: Leg Slippers

What in the Heck Can it Do?

Quick feature list (See complete details at the Vorpal Combat Hexapod Wiki:

  • All parts print with no supports. Some parts do require brims or rafts for proper bed retention to avoid warping. But generally, this is a fairly easy print.
  • 60 different motions directly accessible from the 3D printed gamepad, including modes for walking, dancing and fighting. These can be used for many fun activities for Makers or the classroom. Here are a few sample activities, more are on the Vorpal website:
    Fidget Spinner Challenge Activity Video
    Joust Game Video
    Obstacle Course Activity Video
  • Gamepad has a cool RECORD mode allowing you to record a set of gamepad actions then replay them with a touch of a button, great for classroom activities like "Dance Party!" where students program a choreographed dance routine to a popular song:
    Dance Party Video
  • Magnetic accessory attachments surround the cap, great for decorations, name plates, or small sensors
  • An accessory port on the front of the robot allows you to attach optional accessories for games and combat styles, such as Joust, Capture-The-Flag, heavier sensors like ultrasonic rangefinder, etc.
    We've provided a bunch of 3d printable accessories; feel free to develop more yourself!
  • Plug the gamepad into a computer USB port and it becomes a transmitter for the MIT Scratch drag-and-drop programming language!
    Xylophone Scratch Activity Video
    We have a fully developed set of Scratch extension blocks that let you totally control the robot using Scratch, including reading sensors from the robot and using the values to modify behavior.
    Scratch Obstacle Avoidance Using Ultrasonic Rangefinder Video
    Because many schools use Scratch to introduce programming, this makes the Vorpal Combat Hexapod perfect for educational use!
    For more information see our Vorpal Scratch Programming Guide.
  • We went beyond the call of duty with Scratch: you can program new hexapod actions in Scratch then upload them to gamepad buttons!
    You can have 60 custom actions, triggered by "long tapping" on the mode buttons.
    Short tapping executes the default actions again.
  • 1 hour battery life from commonly available, inexpensive "18650" Li-On batteries (used in many rechargeable flashlights).
    It's like a big fat AA battery and they're about $3 each (two required for the hexapod) and can be recharged 1000 times! Tons of them available on Amazon or other places.
    Gamepad takes a standard 9v transistor battery.
  • All 3D model source files posted publicly on OnShape.com so hack, remix, or extend this design to your heart's content!
  • All Arduino and Scratch source code posted publicly on GitHub (github.com/vorpalrobotics/vorpalhexapod)
  • Complete documentation, including build instructions, games and activities, technical information, gamepad and hexapod user guide, are on our wiki. The main page that can get you to all the other pages is here: (http://vorpalrobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=Vorpal_The_Hexapod) There is a sidebar that has links to other information pages.

Where Do I Get the Electronics Parts List And Build Instructions?

For complete build instructions and bill of materials, see our build instructions page.

Parts are available from many sources but we would of course like you to consider purchasing all or some parts from our store:
Vorpal Robotics Store with Hexapod Kits and Parts

You can purchase full kits, or just the parts you're having trouble finding elsewhere.

The kit that comes from us has these features:

  • Every single non-3D-printed part you need is included, electronics, servo motors, Bluetooth modules, screws, magnets, the whole 9 yards.
  • No soldering required; we did the soldering for you! Great for schools who don't what to deal with soldering.
  • Arduino Nano processors for both gamepad and hexapod are pre-flashed with the control programs; just plug them in and run.
  • Bluetooth modules in each kit are configured to auto-pair on boot. That means, no cryptic "AT" commands or other frustrating setup to do. Again, plug and play.

The only thing the kit does not include is batteries. See below for battery info.

We also do sell the 3D printed parts if you don't have a 3D printer that meets the minimum requirements (5.9" cube build area).

We also sell fully built and tested hexapods for those schools or hobbyists who just want to use this to learn or teach programming, use the activities, etc.

Does This Thing Really Work?

In development for over eighteen months, this has been worked, reworked, an honed to perfection. It was used during a six week STEM program for Appalachian Girls this past summer (8 hexapods) and was a smashing success. We've been invited to the NYC Maker Faire, we've done teacher technology training on board the USS Intrepid Sea, Air, and Space Museum in New York City, gave presentations including hands-on activities at the New Jersey Science Teacher's STEM Conference, and we did a 2 day workshop at the Franklin Institute Science Center in Philadelpha. One of our hexapods is even on display at in the museum's 3D printer section! We've sold hundreds to Makers, schools, hacker spaces, and other organizations. This thing is for real folks, in use by real students and in teacher training, with professional level software to make it work.

Is This Really Open Source?

All the 3D models are open source, along with the Arduino code for both the hexapod and gamepad, as well as the Scratch block extension. All the electronics are items that are either open source (Arduino Nano, Adafruit servo controller) or standard off the shelf items like hobby BEC for power supply and MG90s mini servos.

For specific open source licenses, see our website's Open Source License Info Page.

Where Do I Get the 3D Models, Software Source Code, and Activity Rules?

  • 3D Model Source is posted publicly on OnShape.com, just create a free login then search for Vorpal Combat Hexapod. If you were not aware of it, OnShape is a professional level cloud-based CAD system.
    It's free as long as your project is public, so no cost to you, no install time (runs entirely in your browser). Make a free account in less than a minute and you're up and running with a professional grade system. This site was developed by some of the founders of SolidWorks, so they know what they're doing.

  • Arduino Source Code and Scratch Extension code is posted publicly on GitHub (github.com/vorpalrobotics/vorpalhexapod)

  • Activities suitable for hobbyists, Makers, and schools are posted free on our website's Games and Activities Page.

Battery Info

Gamepad takes a standard 9v transistor battery (either alkaline or rechargeable such as NIMH).

Hexapod takes two 18650 lithium-ion rechargeable batteries. Although many people are not familiar with this kind of battery, they rock. They are commonly available at Amazon and other places because they are used for flashlights. They are cheap: you can get a bundle that includes smart charger and two 18650 batteries for only about $12 to $15.

They are powerful: you get 60 to 80 minutes runtime on the hexapod! They are lightweight, putting less stress on the servo motors. They can be recharged 1000 times. Super economical! You start using these in your projects and you'll never want to use AA or AAA battery packs again, trust me.

(The only reason we don't include these in our kit is that the margins are so low on batteries we would actually lose money by shipping them to people.)

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Tested at 0.38 mm layer but should work at other settings

Infill:

15% recommended

Notes:

Recommended plastic is ABS or PETG. PLA tends to be too brittle. Brims or rafts recommended for the following parts: base, cap, legs, electronics caddy. Heated bed recommended. Minimum bed size is 5.8 inches cube.

Rafts: Some parts need brims or rafts for proper bed retention (I prefer brim; they seem to work fine and are typically easy to remove). The parts that I recommend brims/rafts for are:

  • Legs
  • Base
  • Cap
  • Electronics Caddy

You may find, depending on your printer, that you need brims on:

  • Various nameplates
  • Joust lance
NGSS

There are many different activities available for this project in many different areas. You could fill a whole marking period with different aspects or just concentrate on one. Some examples:
  • You can focus on 3D printing aspects (even for younger grades simply designing a new set of 3D printed "eyes" to magnetically attach is a great intro). For older grades, middle school or high school, have students develop a new game including attachments that must be compatible with the existing robot, game pieces, rules, etc. Brainstorm, design, fabricate (i.e. 3D print and assemble), test, analyze test results, then iterate the design!
  • Introduce concepts such as repeatability by using the RECORD function, then extend this to programmed Scratch projects that stress repeatability.
  • Use Scratch programming to introduce the use of sensors for real world navigation such as obstacle avoidance.
  • Illustrate "Search and Rescue" robots by designing a disaster area using cardboard boxes, have students use the robot to find and rescue "victims".
  • Simulate an exploration robot: send the Vorpal Hexapod to "Mars" and drive (or program) it to take a soil sample, or use a sensor to get a temperature reading.
  • Simulate a military robot used to disarm an improvised explosive device.
  • Teach concepts of walking gaits (tripod, metachronal, ripple, etc.) and discuss advantages and disadvantages of different ways to make a robot walk.

For an extensive list of activities suitable for education, see our Games and Activities page. This is constantly being updated and extended, and we would be glad to hear your ideas for new activities and lessons based on the Vorpal Combat Hexapod.

comments.text: My daughter and I started building ours just yesterday. She's been learning Scratch for a few months now, so she's really excited that Scratch is supported. I printed everything in PLA and had only one issue. When putting the leg hinges together, one did break, but that was it. Twenty minutes later and a fresh one had printed.
comments.author: USSSandhu

comments.text:
While waiting for the second bluetooth module (for the DPAD) I stumbled on a nice generic app to control Arduino's, ESP's etc.: RoboRemo
Configure a button with for instance command "Walk mode 1 forward (W1f)" with the "set press action" : 'sendhex 563103573166F10A'
Yes, hex codes are needed, so for instance http://www.asciitohex.com is handy here.
56= hex for the literal 'V', 31 for 1, 03 for the nr of payload bytes, 57 for 'W', etc.

comments.text: Those are labels for the dial.  Turning the dial to STOP causes the robot to stand still, TST puts it in a test mode for checking servo motors, Demo puts it in an automatic demo mode so you can try it before building the gamepad or just let it run in a display case or something. The other setting, RC, makes it respond to radio control from the gamepad.

comments.text: The kit uses linear. If you use a log pot then the markings on the Base won't match the action the robot does, but assuming you can get to every position it should work to some extent. comments.text: Out of curiosity, what kind of batteries are you using? If the battery is an 18650 with a protection circuit, I've found that some protection circuits are rather over-protective and will cut out very early.  For example, the EBL 3000 mAh that have the white caps around the + terminal work amazingly well, I get 60 to 70 minutes and sometimes even 80.  But the EBL 3000 mAh which have the yellow cap have a much more sensitive protection circuit and I only get 25 minutes before drop outs start happening.
comments.author: adambrum

comments.text: There 18650 unprotected panasonics from a reputable E-cig store, 2500ma.

comments.author: adambrum

comments.text: The need for a divider on the HC05 RX is something of an urban legend. The manufacturer's own documentation clearly shows the RX connected to a 5V uno digital pin with no divider in their example circuit. Nowhere does the documentation ever mention the need for a divider when interfacing with +5v arduinos or other boards.

comments.text: It really depends on which HC05! Some breakout boards have a voltage divider, others  like the  zs-040s dont and require 3.3v TTL.

comments.text: Most slicers have a "minimum layer time" setting. I have that set to 15 seconds, but 20 might be better if you're having this issue. That would do the same thing as the columns without using up plastic.
comments.author: adambrum

comments.text: FWIW, minimum layer time  only slows the print - and only up to a point, as you cant print infinitely slowly, you need to move the hotend or it will melt your print .  Printing Columns has the big advantage of moving the hot end away from the thing you're printing, and is far more effective at cooling. Of course it has its own potential problems, like stringing, but its generally a good strategy if you have insufficient cooling or are printing very small cross sections.
comments.author: vorpal

comments.text: I have tried to setup the scratchx, but only found that the latest chrome and firefox disable the native plugins so the scratchx didn't work well. Would you please let us know the OS and browser version you are using for scratchx, and where to download this version of browser, and how to disable the auto upgrade feature of the browser? Thanks!
comments.author: ruanwz

comments.text: Scratchx hasn't used native plugins on chrome in quite some time, it uses chromium serial io.  Some of the information floating around on forums etc regarding scratchx on chrome are out of date.  i use chrome on windows and mac and it works quite well. The issues many scratchx developers are having getting arduino serial working on scratchx is not a problem with scratchx, it's a problem with the example program MIT points people to, which does not set up data handler callback properly.  (We do it the right way with vorpal).
comments.author: ruanwz

comments.text: I just finished a day long effort to print the cap. First attempt broke off arms and ruined the print. I finally got it to finish on the second try by printing very slow and babysitting it to watch for the nozzle (or even my second nozzle) catching on the very fragile arms. It was quite a mess and I even had to stop the print for adjustments and repairs a couple of times. After I put the whole thing together, I'll probably print the non-skeletonize version. Adding some holes to that version sounds like a good idea and would save time and filament without sacrificing strength. All the other parts printed well. Excellent designs!
comments.author: vorpal

comments.text:
Hello all,
I believe I am the user Vorpal is referring to above that had significant trouble printing the cap. In my case, as the print neared the top, just before solidifying all the little "legs" together, the legs would get caught on the hot end as it moved around. This lead to horrible print quality at least. In several cases, the legs caught so bad that they broke off during the print. I tried printing slower as, Vorpal suggested. But I couldn't find a setting on my slicer (Slic3r Prusa edition) that would limit the print time per layer. Maybe it is there and I missed it?
comments.author: vorpal

comments.text: I'm also having trouble printing the cap.  I resliced the file and it failed in the same place.  The 2 right most ribs start to bow outward and then aren't connected to the top. comments.text: It's possible to print across short distances horizontally as long as there are supporting structures on both sides of the gap. That's called a "bridge". In the case of the cap, the very top is a moderately sized bridge, you may have a couple of drips but they'll be inside so cosmetically  not a problem.

comments.text: Same question as jjohnson98 below re servo bracket play when clipped together. Printed in PLA @ 0.2mm layer height. I don't have any MG90 servos yet (only HobbyKing HXT900's). Will the MG90 servos force the brackets to open at all - which looks like it would reduce the play somewhat.

comments.text: Yes you are correct, the act of placing the servos in the hinge spreads out the U shape and locks them in place. There should be essentially no play at all, or just a tiny bit, depending on your printer settings, how well dialed in it is, etc. Once both servos are installed, each piece clamps down pretty hard on the other piece.

A simple tool I designed to remove bearings out of fidget spinners. The tool consists out of two pieces which are used together with a vice to push the bearing out. Be sure to print this with 100% infill for strength!

To use this, simply place the ring part on one side of the bearing and push the other part into the bearing from the other side. Put the fidget spinner along with these parts together into a vice and keep tightening it until the bearing is out.

I have also included the Blender file in case you want to edit it further.

description.text:
I needed a quick and easy spool holder for my CR-10 after moving the control box under the printer itself with some 3D printed legs (there are models on thingiverse that look much better than the one I'm using, like this one! https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2332197). Instead of printing a frame and spindle and the like, and since I didn't have any ball bearings, I modeled a base that the spool holder that came with the CR-10 could be attached to.

I used two M3 bolts and nuts, but I bet other sizes would work well too. Just make sure to use actual nuts instead of relying on threading into the plastic itself as the spool holder needs to hold up, well, usually a good kilo. Or bad kilo. Your choice of filament here.
Replacement for the hinge of the Bionicon C.Guide v.02 http://www.bionicon.com/ac/c-guide-v02

author: ninharp

description.text:
Goal

Hold the glass tight down on the bed.

Constraints

Don't require a trip to the hardware store
Don't require partial bed disassembly
Minimize interference with head motion
Minimize print area reduction

Design

Clips are tapered and have an opening slightly less than 7mm at the front to grab and stay on. I will update this posting if I find any flaws or improvements.

Printing

I used PLA to eventually discover the failure points. I recommend you use ABS or NY.
PLACE OBJECT VERTICALLY (like a skyskraper, with "C" face on the bed). Duplicate x3 total copies.

Installation

See picture. Put on one side of clip and put counter pressure on opposite side of bed with your hand while installing. Avoid blocking the home position with the front clip.

Fusion 360

Box, Sketch, Extrude with taper

title: Acople para Flexi o correa extensible para perros

description.text:
Es un acople para pegar en el lateral de tu corre para perros ya sea Flexi oficial o otra cualquiera con el lateral plano.

Simplemente hay que pegar la base impresa en el lateral que más te guste o menos te moleste (yo he utilizado pegamento para pvc y se ha quedado perfectamente pegado).

Luego hay que lijar un poco la parte que entra en la base hasta que veas que desliza bien.
Lleva una pequeña pestaña para que no se suelte fácilmente.

Actualización:

He podido comprobar que a la tercera caida, se ha rajado el contenedor por lo que lo he rediseñado con las paredes mas fuertes para soportar alguna que otra caida, el nuevo es el que aparece como AcopleFlexi V4 Ok.

It is a gadget to stick on the side of your dog leash official Flexi or any other with the flat side.

You simply have to stick the printed base on the side that you like or less annoy you (I used glue for pvc and it has been perfectly glued).

Then you have to smear the part that enters the base until you see that it slides well.
Carry a small tab so it does not come off easily.

Upgrade:

I have been able to check that on the third fall, the container has been cracked so I have redesigned it with the strongest walls to withstand some falling, the new one is the one that appears as AcopleFlexi V4 Ok.

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Imprimir sin soportes la parte superior.
La base si que necesita soportes que luego hay que eliminar y lijar hasta que que entre perfecta la parte superior.

Print the upper part without supports.
The base if you need supports that then need to be removed and sanded until the top enters perfectly.

50% fast honeycomb (in S3d)

Notes:

Replacement parts instead of original 2 wheel mounts. Greater stability to reduce the tilt of the X axis.
I designed mating ribs to prevent twisting when pulling the tensioner wheel

I placed the upper belt roller up because the linear guide makes the effector even higher, so the strap runs horizontally.

For the tensioning wheel, an eccentric bore screw is required:
https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/Micrimake-3D-Printer-Parts-Openbuilds-Eccentric-Isolation-Spacer-CNC-Building-Machine-10mm-Wrench-5mm-Bore-20pcs/2128317_32791649596.html? spm = 2114.12010612.0.0.5bdadf47ivAoV8

4pcs for 4mm screw and T nut: https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/Micromake-3D-Printer-Parts-50pcs-lot-M3-M4-Carbon-Steel-T-type-Nuts-Fastener-Aluminum -Connector / 2128317_32685147035.html? spm = 2114.12010612.0.0.5bdadf47O4a2Z6

6pcs wheels: https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/Micromake-3D-Printer-Parts-9pcs-lot-DIY-Black-Pulley-Parts-Pulley-Wheel-New-Injected-Plastic-Wheel/2128317_32774425400 .html? spm = 2114.12010612.0.0.5bdadf47Ipg0ZH

The holes were designed to fit the bolts after printing. If the material is printed in the hole, clean the hole with a suitable drill:
The tension nut bore is 8mm,
the wheel axis is 5mm,
the profile fixing screw 4mm,
the stem wheel axle is 3mm.

title: Targaryen sigil - Game of thrones banner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Targayen sigil from Game of thrones.

Stark version.

Targaryen version.

Greyjoy version.

With the Prusa I3 you can print different layers with different colors. This sigil is made with that in mind. But I also added the model in different parts for multi extruders.

I do intend to publish the other sigils, but it is a slow process (read my profile bio for more information).

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

All versions
You need at least 4 top layers

Complete version:
The first 2mm is supposed to be printed in black. I used 0.2 layers.
For the details I used 0.1 layers.
2.0 - 2.2 white
2.2 - 2.4 red
For Prusa I3 ColorPrint users: You want a color change at 2.1 and 2.3 for these settings.
If you don't know how to use different layer heights, I would recommend 0.1 All the way.

Prusa I3 mk2/s MMU:
The lowest layer height for MMU printing is 0.15mm with the first layer always being 0.2mm
I have included a special version for this.

Select whatever shield thickness you want (1.4mm or 2.0mm).
Use the sigil, text and border labeled "mmu". They are dividable by layerheigh 1.5

Multicolor/part users and MMU
I recommend 3 perimeters on every part, except only 1 perimeter on the two sigil parts.
Also I recommend using "concentric" infill on the part "sigil2", but NOT on "sigil1" ("Rectilinear" is good).

remixed_from.title: AM8 Electronics Case with Dual mosfet

title: AM8 Electronics Case - with fan on enclosure lid

description.text:
In order to ensure better cooling of the RAMPS board and stepper drivers, I modified the lid to allow mounting of a 80mm fan. The lid can probably also be used on the enclosure for the Anet A8 mainboard.

The plan is to use a fan extender on the servo output connector of a RAMPS board to control the fan on the lid of the enclosure (and the fan on the cooling element for the hotend). I have no plans of checking the ability to do this on the Anet mainboard.

I have used a Noctua NF-R8 Redux fan on my single-fan lid (mounted on the outside).

NOTE: I have not printed the dual-fan lid, but it should be possible to mount 2 80mm fans on it.

comments.text: Any chance for a dual 80mm fan cover?

comments.text:
Yes, it must be mounted on the outside (unfortunately). I also considered increasing the height of the enclosure in order to mount the fan on the inside, but this will conflict with the X axis motor.
I know you can get 80mm fans, that only are 10mm in height - which probably would be possible to do with a modified enclosure - but then I would not be able to use my slient 9.1 dB/A 35.8m3/h NF-R8 Redux-1200 Noctua fan :-)

author: Ramirez519

title: B’Struder for grooved, 4mm bearing and gearwheel, fits TRONYX X1.

description.text:
The long story: I broke the air nipple on the X1 extruder. The nipple was a real PITA to start with so no big loss. And I had spares, somewhere. I could not find the spares but I found a M5-nipple and a B’Struder I printed a long time ago. The M5 nipple went on the B’Struder so the B’Struder went on the X1. It worked better then with the broken nipple but not too well . The extruder wheel I had was for 3mm filament and I could not get the spring tension right. I like the B’Struder a lot, except for the spring that is hard to fit and hard to get right. On the other hand, the solution for the spring on the X1 is nice, I had all the other hardware and a few M10 air nipples. So I fired up the CAD and made a B’Struder for the X1 parts minus the nipple. It works great. I had to reverse the extruder motor in the first extruder change. The process involves fidgeting around with very small plastic parts that easily brake with grave consequences. I decided against restoring the rotation to original.

PLEASE NOTE!!
The pictures show a CV extruder, the X1 motor is CCV original!

Also note that the base of this B’Struder is thinner then on the original because of the plate holding the motor.

Happy printing!

Runcam 2 Lens Cover

Simple bracket that snaps onto head tube of Razor A5 Lux kick scooter and provides clips to hold the handles in place and a loop to clip a strap to carry the scooter.

There isn't an obvious place to put the other end of the carry strap without taking apart the scooter or drilling a hole into the fork so I just printed buckles and used 1" webbing that loops through the front wheel back toward the loop on the bracket into a keychain carabiner.

Note that I have the version of the A5 Lux with the wider handlebars. I don't know if it works with the narrow handlebar version. The bracket may need to clip onto the "stem" instead if the bars are too short in which case it would need to be resized.

Not sure of the durability of this over a clamp with a bolt so use at your own risk. I just needed an easy way to shoulder carry the scooter every so often.

Designed in TinkerCAD.

title: Chain Whip Bike Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A bicycle chain whip handle I designed. It's a very simple design and easy to print.

Uses 3 M5x45mm long bolts, 3 M5 nuts ans some old bike chain.
Included 3 different lengths for different sized printers. (99mm, 119mm and 169mm)

I printed the 169mm long one out of PLA. (35% infill, 3mm thick walls and .17mm layer heights.) It was a 6 hour print but seems to be super strong. I've used it a few times to swap out the cogs on my single speed mountain bike. So far its holding up well. It may also be strong enough with thinner walls and larger layer heights but I don't know.

description.text: So this took all of my skills at 3D drafting to design this highly detailed thing (that's sarcasm by the way). I just whipped this up in Sketchup, printed with 1 bottom, 2 perimeters, and 2 tops with a 25% infill. They fit and function perfectly. Obviously print two and glue together.

title: 24 LED Neopixel Glasses for Arduino nano

description.text:
This is a remix of 4 existing files in order to make a pair of self contained Neopixel glasses using two 24 LED Neopixel rings, and an Arduino Nano processor.

Updated Lenses File 2017-09-03
I realized the lenses file started the print off the heatbed, and it made the front of the glasses "less attractive" since the supports needed to be trimmed off. That s now fixed. The new file has holes on both sides for the wiring as well in case you'd like to put the processor on one side and the battery on the other. The centre hole is also larger to accommodate the ribbon cable. I also updated the firmware, it does what the video shows and more.

I tried to hide the wiring inside the frames as much as possible, the bridge between the two rings is hollow for that purpose. Unfortunately one side is heavy, so I added an elastic to the back to keep the glasses on securely.

If you decide to use a different processor, you can mirror the left arm and add what you need instead of trying to remove the box on the right arm used to house the Arduino Nano.

Needed to build:

3D printed parts, - Print one -Glasses new, one left arm, one right arm, and 2 pins
2x 24 LED Neopixel rings- by Adafruit or on Ebay
1 foot - 3 conductor ribbon cable
1/8 inch drill - to clean out the holes in the arm for the arduino wires
3/16 inch drill - to clean out the holes for the arm pins
7.2v LI battery, or a battery of your choice that will run the processor and LEDs (I used 2 3.7v 180mah batteries in series)
connector for the battery
Nailfile emery board - to sand the edges that will be close to the face, and to round the pins so they are easier to move.
soldering iron
hot glue gun - to secure the rings in the glasses
Arduino Nano with no pins.
You will also need to program the Arduino Nano with the source code. You will need the Adafruit_NeoPixel library. I reduced the brightness in the code so that you don't burn out the Arduino 5v regulator. They are still bright enough. Solder the tx wire to pin D3.
The code is from Adafruit.

how to build them: https://youtu.be/5INxMYqkB98

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-AmBkx18Krw&feature=youtu.be

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I used support only when "Touching buildplate" for the Glasses rings, This makes it easier to use the holes for the arms, and the hole in the bridge is then open, if you forget and put support "everywhere" the wire won't be able to go through the centre bridge hole since it's clogged with support plastic.

The arms need support everywhere. I use ZigZag, 5mm support line distance.It seems to be easy enough to remove with needle-nose pliers.
